Project Description  The  Tsunami  Emergency  Assistance  Project  (the  Project)  will 
rehabilitate and restore damage caused by the December 2004 
tsunami, thereby restoring the livelihoods of the affected people. 
The  Project’s  design  is  based  on  the  findings  of  a  needs 
assessment report, prepared for the Government jointly by ADB, 
the UN, and the World Bank in January and February 2005. Local 
communities  and  beneficiaries  will  actively  participate  in  the 
selection,  design,  implementation,  and  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) of all works carried out under the Project.  
   
Rationale  The tsunami had a devastating impact on the Maldives. Eighty-
three  people  are  confirmed  dead  and  another  twenty-five  are 
missing, feared dead. More than 1,300 people suffered injuries. 
Unlike  other  countries  affected  by  the  tsunami,  the  Maldives 
experienced a disaster of national proportions. Thirty-nine islands 
were significantly damaged and nearly a third of the Maldives’ 
300,000  people  were  severely  affected.  About  7%  of  the 
population of the Maldives was displaced. Thousands of people 
had their livelihoods undermined and they will continue to suffer 
unless immediate mitigating measures are taken. Total damage is 
estimated to be about $470 million, close to 62% of GDP. About 
$298 million is direct damages, and the rest is indirect losses. The 
direct damages amount to about 8% of the replacement cost of 
the entire national capital stock, estimated to be about $3.8 billion 
at  2004  prices.  The  tourism  sector  suffered  the  largest  direct 
damages,  with  losses  of  around  $100  million,  followed  by  the 
housing sector, with losses close to $65 million.

ii   
  The combined impact of the tsunami will reduce GDP growth in 
2005 significantly from the pre-tsunami estimate of 7.5% to 1%. 
The  impact  on  public  finances  is  likely  to  be  substantial.  The 
budget  deficit  (including  grants)  is  expected  to  rise  from  a 
projected 4% of GDP to around 10% of GDP; excluding grants, 
the deficit would amount to 18% of GDP. There are concerns 
about the sustainability of the deficit and how it will be financed. 
The external balance is also expected to worsen. The current 
account deficit of the balance of payments is expected to worsen 
to about 23% of GDP in 2005, compared with 12% in 2004. It is 
estimated that the financing gap of the balance of payments will 
be $68 million in 2005. Significant external financing is needed, in 
the form of grants and concessional loans to the government, as 
well as private funds, to finance the budget and the widening 
current account deficit of the balance of payments. In undertaking 
additional  external  liability  for  post-tsunami  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction, the Government of Maldives (the Government) will 
need to be particularly careful to avoid increasing external debt to 
uncomfortable  levels,  which  could  have  a  negative  impact  on 
future growth. External debt (public and private) could rise to 47% 
of GDP in 2005 (from about 42% in 2004). Hence, grants will be 
the  preferred  mode  of  external  assistance  for  financing  post-
tsunami rehabilitation and reconstruction. 
   
Objectives and Scope  The  main  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  contribute  to  the 
sustainability of economic growth by minimizing the devastating 
impact of the tsunami. To attain this, economic recovery needs to 
be accelerated through reconstruction of damaged infrastructure 
and restoration of means of livelihood, especially of the poor, in 
the affected islands.  
 
The  Project  will  have  two  components  (i)  a  quick-disbursing 
component, and (ii) a project component.  
   
  The Quick-Disbursing Component will partially finance the high 
and  unexpected  Government  expenditures  on  tsunami-related 
rehabilitation,  and  reconstruction.  In  accordance  with  the 
requirements  of  ADB’s  Disaster  and  Emergency  Assistance 
Policy, the quick-disbursing component of the proposed Project 
will be used only to finance imports identified as necessary for an 
effective  recovery  program.  The  Government  and  ADB  have 
agreed on a list of imports that can be financed under the quick-
disbursing Project facility.

iii
  The Project Component will rehabilitate high-priority, tsunami-
damaged  infrastructure  and  facilities  by  providing  civil  works, 
equipment and materials, working capital, and consulting services 
for project design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation. The 
project  component  will  follow  a  sector  approach  to  selecting 
subprojects,  based  on  agreed  criteria.  Following  consultations 
with the Government and development partners, the sectors listed 
below have been included in this component. The rehabilitation 
and reconstruction work will be carried out to restore facilities to 
pre-tsunami  levels,  or  to  higher,  more  cost-effective  and 
environmentally-sustainable standards.  Where necessary, project 
designs will include protection measures against future natural 
disasters. 
   
  A.  Water Supply, Sanitation and Solid Waste Management. 
This includes (i) rehabilitation and reconstruction of infrastructure 
damaged by the tsunami (including sewage systems, networks 
and outfalls), (ii) provision of water and sewage treatment and 
disposal  facilities  for  displaced  populations  after  the  tsunami 
rendered their islands uninhabitable, and (iii) provision of solid 
waste management systems and facilities. 
   
  B.  Transport. This includes (i) rehabilitation and/or reinstatement 
of  damaged  or  destroyed  maritime  navigation  aids, 
(ii) procurement of emergency inter-island transport capacity for 
reconstruction  works,  (iii)  rehabilitation  of  damaged  jetties, 
(iv) repairs to sea walls and quay walls, (v) repairs to causeways, 
(vi)  dredging  of  harbor  basins  and  approach  channels,  and 
(vii) rehabilitation of Malé international airport. 
   
  C.  Power.  This  includes  rehabilitation  of  the  damaged  power 
supply  system  and  covers  supply  and  installation  of  new 
generators  and  distribution  network,  including  cables  and 
distribution boxes.  Streetlights will also be installed, if necessary. 
In bigger islands, with more than one generator, panel boards will 
be  provided  to  synchronize  operations.  In  islands  where 
powerhouses are badly damaged, new ones will be constructed.  
   
  D.  Fisheries.  This  includes  providing  fish  processors  in  128 
islands with processing equipment, working capital, and extension 
services.  The capacity of the Ministry of Fisheries, Agriculture, 
and Marine Resources (MFAMR) will also be strengthened.  
   
  E.  Agriculture. This includes providing affected farmers in the 
perennial and field crop sectors with tools and equipment, and 
working capital to rehabilitate their farms.

iv   
Cost Estimates  The  estimated  cost  of  the  Project  is  $25.3  million  equivalent, 
including the quick-disbursing component, which will be entirely in 
foreign exchange. For the project component, the Government will 
contribute  19%  of  the  estimated  cost  of  reconstruction  and 
rehabilitation,  mainly  in  the  form  of  exemption  of  taxes  and 
administrative support. 
   
Financing Plan  ADB will provide a grant of $20 million from the Asian Tsunami 
Fund  (ATF)  and  a  loan  of  $1.8  million  in  various  currencies 
equivalent to SDR1,188,000 from its Special Funds resources to 
finance 86% of the total project cost. This covers the entire foreign 
exchange cost of $16.5 million and $5.3 million equivalent of local 
currency cost.

Executing Agencies  The  Executing  Agency  will  be  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and 
Treasury  (MOFT).  A  National  Economic  Recovery  and 
Reconstruction Program (NERRP) has been created to deal with 
(i) national economic recovery under the MOFT, and (ii) housing 
and infrastructure redevelopment under the Ministry of Planning 
and National Development (MPND). 
   
Implementation  The  recently  created  NERRP  will  manage  implementation  of 
Arrangements  tsunami-related rehabilitation and reconstruction projects. Its tasks 
include: (i) planning and implementation of the reconstruction and 
rehabilitation of affected islands; (ii) coordination of the recovery 
of the national economy; and (iii) planning and implementation of 
long-term  projects  within  the  national  development  framework. 
The NERRP mainly consists of staff from  MOFT, who  will be 
handling the economic recovery, and from MPND, who will be 
dealing  with  infrastructure  reconstruction.  The  Project  will  be 
implemented by a centralized PMU to be created under NERRP, 
so  that  the  Government  does  not  need  to  form  a  new  and 
separate PMU for the Project. MOFT will, however, appoint a 
dedicated  project  manager  to  coordinate  and  oversee  the 
Project’s implementation.  The project manager will be supported 
by five units, under NERRP: (i) planning and programming, (ii) 
procurement,  (iii)  finance  and  accounting,  (iv)  monitoring  and 
evaluation,  and  (v)  technical  and  implementation.  The  project 
manager and the five units will be the project management unit 
(PMU) for the Project. The technical ministries and agencies will 
be the implementing agencies (IAs).  They will assign staff to the 
PMU's technical and implementation unit, and will be responsible 
for technical matters relating to their respective sectoral expertise, 
as follows: 
   
  (i)  Ministry of Health (MOH) and Ministry of Environment and 
Construction  (MEC)  in  the  water  supply,  sanitation  and 
solid waste management sector; 
(ii)  Ministry of Atolls Development (MOAD), and Ministry of 
Transport  and  Civil  Aviation  (MTCA)  in  the  transport 
sector; 
(iii)  Ministry of  Fisheries, Agriculture and Marine  Resources 
(MFAMR), in the agriculture and fisheries sectors; and 
(iv)  State Electricity Company Limited (STELCO) in the power 
sector. 
   
  In addition, MOAD will coordinate activities at the atolls level.

vi   
  To  ensure  coordination  among  sectors,  the  Government  will 
establish a project coordinating committee (PCC). The PCC will 
be co-chaired by the Minister of Finance and Treasury and the 
Minister  of  Planning  and  National  Development,  or  their 
designates, and will include high-level representatives from MPND 
and  the  IAs,  as  well  as  the  Ministry  of  Gender,  Family 
Development and Social Security, and the Department of External 
Resources. The PCC will provide guidance to the PMU on policy 
matters,  and  will  decide  on  the  selection  of  high-priority 
subprojects proposed by the PMU. The PMU will be responsible 
for (i) consolidating subproject proposals from the implementing 
agencies to be submitted for approval by the PCC; (ii) preparing 
bidding documents and conducting procurement of civil works, 
equipment,  goods,  and  related  services  for  infrastructure 
reconstruction; (iii) recommending the release of funds for working 
capital  to  the  affected  communities;  (iv)  disbursing  funds  and 
accounting,  including  preparing  the  financial  reports;  and 
(v) preparing and submitting progress reports to PCC and ADB.  
 
The Project’s funds will be disbursed through subaccounts under 
the Tsunami Relief and Reconstruction Fund (TRRF), created by 
the Government, to (i) ensure transparency and harmonization, (ii) 
avoid  duplication  of  effort,  and  (iii)  reduce  administrative 
overheads.  The  TRRF  will  follow  international  accounting 
standards,  and  will  have  a  financial  management  system  to 
account and report for project resources and expenditures. 
   
Procurement  Procurement of goods, services and works will be carried out in 
accordance  with  the  ADB  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  
Procurement  will  be  expedited  to  meet  the  contemplated 
implementation  schedule.  ADB’s  procedures  for  providing 
reconstruction assistance after disasters provide for flexibility, so 
that project activities can start promptly. Local procurement will be 
the preferred mode for all civil works because of the relatively 
short implementation period, the small size of contract packages, 
and the wide geographic spread of the project sites. Community 
participation will be encouraged. The flexibility provided in ADB’s 
Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy will be used where 
applicable. Prior review by ADB of invitations for bids and bidding 
documents shall be required for procurement under international 
competitive bidding procedures.  For  international  shopping   and 
local  competitive  bidding  procurement,  post  facto  approval 
procedures will be followed. However, if ADB does not approve 
the award or terms of the contract, the Government will not use 
grant funds to finance the contract. If grant funds have been used, 
the Government will refund to ADB any such payments.

vii
  The procurement of goods, related services, and works through 
international  shopping,  local  competitive  bidding,  and  other 
procurement methods shall follow the government’s procedures 
and  bidding  documents  established  for  TRRF  and  found 
acceptable to ADB. Initial scrutiny indicates that the government’s 
existing procedures and bidding documents are broadly in line 
with ADB’s requirements. 
   
Consulting Services  Given the tight implementation schedule and the limited capacity 
of IAs, consulting services will be required to assist the PMU in 
(i) prioritization of subprojects; (ii) technical survey and detailed 
design  of  subprojects;  (iii)  preparation  of  cost  estimates; 
(iv) preparation  of  subproject  proposals  in  accordance  with 
selection  criteria  agreed  between  ADB  and  the  Government; 
(v) supervision and monitoring of works to ensure quality control 
and transparency among contractors and communities carrying 
out smaller works; and (vi) oversight of works in each sector or 
subsector  and  provision  of  detailed  accounting,  auditing,  and 
reporting to PCC and ADB. The Project will require a total of 27 
person-months of international and 63 person-months of domestic 
consultants. Consultants will be engaged by ADB, in consultation 
with the Government, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB 
for the engagement of domestic consultants. Since the Project will 
be  completed  within  24  months,  ADB  has  agreed  with  the 
Government that direct engagement of individual consultants be 
undertaken, as provided for under the guidelines.  
   
Project Benefits and  The  Project  will  contribute  to  ongoing  Government  efforts  in 
Beneficiaries  economic recovery; public infrastructure and utilities rehabilitation; 
livelihood and employment generation; and promotion of social 
cohesion. It will help restore access to public infrastructure and 
services. It will help to maintain clean living conditions through 
community-based  water  supply,  sanitation  and  solid  waste 
management programs. The Project will also help re-establish lost 
agricultural  and  fishing  incomes  through  livelihood  programs 
targeted  at  workers  in  the  agricultural  and  fisheries  sectors, 
especially   women   who   engage   in   home  gardening  and fish 
  processing. Interventions proposed within each sector will help 
restore  the  livelihoods  of  many  tsunami-affected  and  internally 
displaced people. The priority given to providing unskilled work to 
affected  people,  including  women,  will  be  an  important 
intervention for people who cannot re-establish their livelihoods 
and  are  living  in  temporary  shelters.  The  Project  will  help  to 
restore the confidence and self-dignity of people and communities 
adversely affected by the tsunami.

viii  
Risks and Assumptions  A  potential  risk  is  that,  despite  the  Government’s  strong 
commitment, implementation could be hampered by slow approval 
procedures  and  lack  of  adequate  capacity  in  the  IAs.  The 
Government  has  streamlined  the  approval  procedures  for  all 
projects, and a PCC will be established to ensure coordination 
among sectors during implementation. The PCC will have high-
level  political  and  administrative  representation.  It  will  provide 
guidance  to  the  centralized  PMU  on  policy  matters,  and 
specifically will decide on the selection of high-priority subprojects 
proposed  by  the  PMU.  The  selected  IAs  have  considerable 
experience  in  implementing  ADB-financed  projects  and  are 
familiar with ADB procedures. Specialized consultancy inputs will 
provide additional implementation assistance to the PMU and the 
IAs. 
 
  Governance-related  issues,  including  corruption,  constitute 
another risk. They are addressed by detailed subproject selection 
criteria, transparent implementation and monitoring mechanisms, 
and specific financial controls, including regular as well as random 
audits.  These  will  include  strict  construction  supervision  and 
adequate  consultant  support,  and  close  monitoring  by  ADB’s 
Extended  Mission  (EM)  and  Headquarters  staff.  Random 
procurement and annual performance auditing at the executing 
agency (EA) level will also be carried out. A dedicated project 
manager  will  assist  in  selection  and  implementation  of 
subprojects. In addition, the Government will involve community-
based  organizations  (CBOs),  island  development  committees 
(IDCs), and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) in monitoring 
project implementation. Consultants and the PMU will determine 
specific  monitoring  indicators  for  outputs  of  sectors  and 
subprojects.  The  Government  will  establish  a  grievance 
mechanism to give tsunami-affected people an opportunity to be 
heard and to submit any complaints related to ADB’s proposed 
assistance.  For  this  purpose,      facilitation      units      will      be  
established   to   assist individuals and communities   to   access  
goods  and  services  financed  under  the  Project,  or  other 
assistance for tsunami-affected people. Such facilitation units will 
be established in collaboration with CBOs and NGOs. The PMU 
will also publicly disclose information on project procurement on 
the website for the Project. The website will provide information on 
financial statements, bidding procedures, bidders, and contract 
awards for the Project. ADB’s EM staff and consultants will help to 
create the website. Checks and balances will be maintained by 
consultants, who, in addition to providing specialized inputs into 
the design of subprojects, will conduct random spot checks during 
the Project implementation and provide capacity building inputs in 
such areas as monitoring and evaluation.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
and loan to the Republic of the Maldives for the Tsunami Emergency Assistance Project (the 
Project)  to  partially  reconstruct  damaged  infrastructure  and  restore  livelihoods  that  were 
severely affected by the tsunami that struck the Indian Ocean on 26 December 2004. The 
Design and Monitoring Framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: ANALYSIS, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Impact of the Tsunami on the Maldives 
2.  The tsunami traveled at over 700 kilometers per hour and reached the Maldives at 09:20 
in the morning of 26 December 2004. Tidal waves ranging from 4 to 14 feet were reported in all 
parts of the country. More than 1,300 people were injured, 83 people are confirmed dead and 
another  25  are  missing,  feared  dead.  Unlike  other  countries  affected  by  the  tsunami,  the 
Maldives experienced a disaster of national proportions. Thirty-nine islands were significantly 
damaged and nearly a third of the Maldives’ 300,000 people were severely affected. Fourteen 
islands  were  completely  destroyed  and  evacuated.  More  than  12,500  people  have  been 
displaced from their islands, and another 8,500 have been temporarily relocated within their own 
islands. About 7% of the population of the Maldives was displaced. The force of the waves 
caused widespread devastation of shelter and infrastructure in the atolls. Flooding wiped out 
electricity on many islands, simultaneously destroying communication links. Water supply was 
disrupted in about 15% of islands and 18% had major damage to essential infrastructure, such 
as the jetties and harbors, that links them to Malé. The electricity supply in many affected 
islands has yet to be restored. The impact on an economy dependent largely on tourism, 
fisheries,  and  agriculture  has  been  significant.  The  livelihoods  of  thousands  have  been 
undermined and they will continue to suffer unless immediate mitigating measures are taken. 
B.  The Government's Immediate Response 
3.  The Government of the Maldives (the Government) acted quickly, and an impressive 
relief and rehabilitation operation was put in place with support from UN agencies, NGOs, and 
other development partners. The President of the Maldives declared a state of national disaster 
and appeals were made for international assistance. A National Disaster Management Centre 
(NDMC)  was  established  to  expedite  and  facilitate  coordination  of  rescue  and  relief.  The 
Ministry of Defense (MOD) is coordinating the overall relief effort, while the Ministry of Finance 
and  Treasury  (MOFT)  is  coordinating  donor  assistance.  The  Ministry  of  Planning  and 
Development (MPND) is coordinating data gathering and long-term responses.  
 
4.  Communication was restored on 11 atolls within 24 hours of the tsunami and relief 
supplies were dispatched from 27 December 2004. Communities mobilized in support of their 
neighbors and the private sector also contributed to the relief effort.  
 
C.  Needs Assessment 
5.  The Government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on 28 December 2004 for 
emergency assistance for relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction in response to the damage 
caused by the tsunami. In consultation with the Government, ADB, the World Bank, and the UN 
formed a team to undertake a needs assessment. The assessment began on 5 January 2005, 
and an interim report was presented to the Government on 17 January 2005. The report was

revised based on comments received from the Government and other development partners. 
The Government endorsed the findings of the report on 15 February 2005 (the full needs

D.  Estimated Reconstruction Costs and Financing Requirements 
6.  Total damages are estimated to be about $470 million, close to 62% of GDP. About 
$298 million is direct damages, and the rest is indirect losses. The cost of direct damages 
amount to about 8% of the replacement cost of the entire national capital stock, estimated at 
around $3.8 billion at 2004 prices. The tourism sector suffered the largest direct damages, with 
losses of $100 million, followed by the housing sector with losses close to $65 million. The 
largest indirect losses also occurred in the tourism sector, which has seen a sharp drop in 
tourist arrivals. 
7.  Reconstruction costs are higher than total losses for some sectors (e.g. housing).  This 
is because of the need to rebuild to higher standards to reduce vulnerability and because 
current construction or environmental standards are higher than when the original facilities were 
built. Some indirect losses cannot be recovered: production losses from fishing and agriculture, 
and  tourism  cancellations  cannot  be  restored.  There  are  both  short-term  and  long-term 
financing needs. The short-term needs reflect investments needed urgently within the next 6 
months; the long-term needs cover the period from 6 months to 3 years. The overall financing 
needs for the next 3 years are expected to be $406 million; of this, $120 million will be needed 
within the next 6 months i.e. in first half of 2005 (Appendix 2, Table A2.1). 
E.  Macroeconomic Impact 
8.  The tsunami has severely affected key economic sectors, including tourism, fisheries, 
agriculture, and essential infrastructure, including water supply, sanitation and power.  The 
impact on these sectors will spill over into other sectors. The tsunami will decelerate GDP 
growth substantially. Economic growth forecasts for 2005 have been revised downwards from 
the pre-tsunami estimate of 7.5% to 1%. The impact of the tsunami on public finances is likely to 
be substantial. The budget deficit (including grants) is expected to rise from a projected 4% of 
GDP to around 10% of GDP. The budget deficit, excluding grants, will amount to 18% of GDP. 
There are concerns about the sustainability of the deficit and how it will be financed. Given the 
limited maneuvering space for the government as a result of deficit spending in the recent past, 
a lack of finance could constrain reconstruction spending. The balance of payments is expected 
to deteriorate because of a slowdown in the tourism industry and the imports needed for 
reconstruction.  However,  increases  in  official  transfers  and  remittances  may  mitigate  this 
somewhat. Overall, the current account deficit of the balance of payments is expected to rise 
sharply to about 23% of GDP from 12% in 2004. The financing gap of the balance of payments 
is estimated at $68 million in 2005 after adjusting for a substantial increase in expected external 
assistance. Additional external financing is needed, in the form of grants and concessional loans 
to the Government, as well as more private funds, to finance the budget and the widening 
current account deficit of the balance of payments. 
 
9.  The  terms  under  which  external  finance  is  available  will  determine  the  pace  of 
reconstruction. It needs to be emphasized that, in undertaking post-tsunami rehabilitation and 
reconstruction, the Government will need to be particularly careful not to run up its external debt 
to uncomfortable levels, which could affect future growth prospects. It is anticipated that the 
private sector will increase foreign borrowing, in order to finance the liquidity of banks and the 
reconstruction of resorts. This could raise total external debt sharply. Hence, to the extent

rehabilitation and reconstruction (for the macroeconomic impact see Appendix 3). 
 
F.  National Recovery and Reconstruction Plan 
10.  The Government has recently prepared a National Recovery and Reconstruction Plan 
(NRRP).1 The NRRP outlines the projects and programs required to meet the immediate needs 
for housing and infrastructure, reviving livelihoods, and creating the conditions for sustained 
economic recovery. The priorities and objectives for recovery and reconstruction are: (i) disaster 
relief (to help survivors cope with the immediate aftermath of the disaster); (ii) macroeconomic 
recovery and livelihood revival (to restore community livelihoods, revive key economic sectors, 
and maintain macroeconomic stability); (iii) community empowerment (to rebuild lives with local 
ownership);  (iv)  environmental  protection  (to  protect  and  regenerate  vulnerable  marine 
ecosystems, strengthen disaster preparedness, and mitigation measures); and (v) restoration of 
public services (so everyone has access to basic services). 
 
11.  The NRRP has identified provision of emergency shelter to the displaced population as 
the most important priority. The economic recovery plan is based on a stable and sustainable 
macroeconomic framework, and aims to revive the tourism and fisheries sectors in the shortest 
possible time. In the event of resettlement because of the tsunami, the NRRP categorically 
states that such resettlement will be demand-driven and voluntary. The NRRP also emphasizes 
the need to rebuild infrastructure in the 104 most affected islands. These include schools, 
hospitals, coastal structures, transportation and communication infrastructure, water supply and 
sewerage, solid waste disposal systems, and electricity. The NRRP also supports establishment 
of stronger disaster mitigation measures, and protection of the environment. It proposes an 
investment program of $375 million in 13 sectors. The document also contains a sector based 
Results  and  Resource  Framework.  Prioritization  of  projects  within  sectors  has  yet  to  be 
completed.

H.  Social, Poverty, Environment, and Livelihood Impact 
15.  Social Impact. The social fabric of the tsunami-hit islands has been seriously affected 
by the extensive physical damage, loss of life and livelihoods, and displacement of people. Most 
affected people lost savings kept in cash in the house. The affected communities are now more 
vulnerable to poverty. Although traumatized, island communities have demonstrated a strong 
sense of independence, resilience and cohesion in mobilizing themselves into groups to remove 
rubble, initiate small-scale reconstruction activities, distribute relief supplies, and shelter those 
made homeless. In a country of many small islands, community organizations have traditionally 
played an important role in providing public and collective services. The capacity of communities 
to mobilize themselves will be an important asset for the reconstruction work ahead. Community 
mobilization and self-help will be a cornerstone and organizing principle for demand-driven local 
recovery programs. The planned reconstruction activities will be made socially more cohesive 
by taking into account the special needs of women, whose livelihoods have been especially 
affected by the tsunami. Livelihood recovery interventions need to support women’s income 
generation. Post-tsunami rehabilitation and reconstruction programs also offer an opportunity to 
enhance the capacities of government departments and island communities in planning and 
implementing the recovery effort.

16.  Displacement.  Some  people  have  moved  to  other  islands,  either  temporarily  or 
permanently. While most affected people will return to their original islands, some communities 
will be resettled either out of choice (the community wants to move to a larger or safer island) or 
out  of  necessity  (the  home  island  has  been  completely  destroyed,  submerged,  or  made 
uninhabitable). The government has clearly stated that nobody will be forced to relocate against 
their wishes. 
17.  Poverty. The tsunami may lead to an increase in poverty as a result of exacerbated 
regional disparities, magnified gender differences, and an increase in migration to Malé. An 
estimated 70% of the population outside of Malé has an income equivalent to the poorest 20% 
in Malé. Almost 52% of the affected population is female. The vulnerability of the poor has 
increased  in  the  post-tsunami  period  because  of  (i)  the  unclean  environment  and  the 
consequent risk of disease; (ii) the damaged maritime and air infrastructure, limiting safe travel; 
(iii) destruction of public utilities and discontinued power supply; and (iv) destroyed livelihoods in 
agriculture and fisheries. Poor and disadvantaged households, especially those headed by 
women,  are  particularly  affected  by  these  shocks  and  face  a  risk  of  becoming  further 
marginalized. 
18.  Environment. Even more than most island nations, the Maldives is highly dependent on 
the  fragile  ecosystem  of  its  coral  reef  islands.  The  tsunami  has  generated  a  range  of 
environmental  problems  with  the  potential  to  harm  human  health.  It  caused  widespread 
deposition of coral sand, vegetation, municipal waste from dump sites, health care waste, 
human excreta from damaged septic tanks, hazardous substances (oils, asbestos, batteries, 
etc.) and demolition waste (concrete, coral fragments, timber, etc.) from destroyed buildings 
across the impacted islands. It resulted in saltwater intrusion into fresh water sources on almost 
all of the 1,200 islands, causing vegetation to go brown and die. It is likely that the coral reefs 
around some islands have been damaged by sedimentation and excessive amounts of debris. 
In addition, the tsunami resulted in beach and soil erosion.  
19.  Safety  Nets,  Employment,  and  Livelihoods.  The  tsunami  has  created  a  new 
vulnerable group; people who lost their houses, other assets, and livelihoods. How quickly they 
recover depends critically on the amount, speed, and efficiency of targeted public support for 
employment creation and livelihood restoration.  As a step in this direction, the Government has 
launched the Island Livelihood Revitalization and Development Program. This program provides

capital; (iii) subsidized microcredit for agricultural and other producers; (iv) financing for repairs 
to fishing vessels; and (v) procurement of new cost-effective fishing vessels to replace those 
that were lost. At the same time, the Government recognizes that some affected households 
may not be able to benefit from such livelihood assistance, and will need targeted interventions.

I.  National Disaster Risk Management 
20.  The recent disaster has increased Government awareness of the risk exposure of the 
Maldives and the measures needed to manage that risk. The Government is preparing a risk-
management strategy to reduce the human and economic impact of future disasters. The three 
pillars of risk management are risk information, risk mitigation, and risk transfer.  
21.  The first pillar, risk information, aims to increase the understanding of risk, based on an 
assessment of vulnerability. The Government plans to participate in a regional warning system 
and develop a national communications program to inform island representatives and local 
communities. Preparedness planning would be put in place for first response and emergency 
relief and a broadband communications network is planned.  Updated information, based on a 
comprehensive risk mapping, would be made available to the population.  
22.  The second pillar, risk mitigation, includes structural and nonstructural measures. The 
nonstructural measures include changes to the legal and regulatory system, particularly with 
regard to land use planning and the building code, so the reconstruction process can lead to a 
reduction in risk. Land use plans would incorporate risk mapping information to reflect different 
levels of risks in the zoning. The building code would introduce construction requirements to 
limit the vulnerability of the built environment. Risk mitigation needs to be complemented by the 
identification of shelters, and the construction, or adaptation, of multipurpose shelters. 
23.  The third pillar, risk transfer, would attempt to distribute risk among the Government, 
households, and insurance companies. Sectors such as tourism, fisheries, and banking, in 
particular, could benefit from insurance against risk.

K.  Lessons in Disaster Management 
26.  ADB has not provided disaster emergency assistance to the Maldives before. This will 
be only the second project developed under ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy 
(May 2004);9 the first being the Emergency Flood Damage Rehabilitation Project in Bangladesh 
that was approved in January 2005. Some general lessons can nevertheless be drawn based 
on the experience of other developing member countries (DMCs), most notably of Bangladesh, 
where ADB has provided eight postdisaster loans.10 The general lessons are that (i) projects 
must  be  prepared  as  quickly  as  possible;  (ii)  they  should  focus  on  restoring  facilities; 
(iii) rehabilitation  works,  to  the  extent  possible,  should  be  completed  within  2  years; 
(iv) implementation will place a heavy burden on executing agency staff and, therefore, strong 
consulting support and ADB supervision will be needed during implementation; and (v) efforts 
should be made to ensure that ADB’s rapid response to disasters is matched by equally quick 
action by the Government.  
 
27.  Other lessons learned from ADB’s earlier emergency projects are that (i) beneficiary 
participation is important and should be increased in project preparation and implementation, 
especially  in  the  maintenance  of  facilities;  (ii)  environment  and  social  aspects need  to  be 
considered during implementation, even though the need for a rapid response may not permit 
detailed treatment before approval; (iii) arrangements for disbursements, including retroactive 
financing and the use of imprest accounts, should give the executing agency quick and simple 
access to funds; (iv) project objectives and scope need to be carefully defined; and (v) criteria 
for  subproject  selection  should  permit  simple  prioritization  of  subprojects  and  short 
implementation periods. In addition, anticorruption measures need to be addressed even in 
emergency projects. These lessons have been considered and incorporated in the design of the 
proposed Project for Maldives.

harbor basins and approach channels. Five causeways, which are very important for inter-island 
connections, have been partly damaged. There has been some damage to Malé’s commercial 
harbor and international airport, part of which will be covered by insurance. However, for safety 
reasons, the airport requires short-term repair work on the airfield, drainage works, sea wall 
defenses, navigation equipment, and communications. 
 
43.  The transport project component comprises: (i) rehabilitation and/or reinstatement of 
maritime navigation aids that have been damaged or destroyed; (ii) procurement of emergency 
inter-island transport capacity for reconstruction works; (iii) rehabilitation of damaged jetties; (iv) 
repairs to sea walls and quay walls; (v) repairs to causeways; (vi) dredging of harbor basins and 
approach channels; and (vii) rehabilitation of the Malé International Airport. Rehabilitation works 
will be carried out to restore facilities to pre-tsunami levels or to a higher standard as considered

11 
cost-effective in the long run, and, where appropriate, will include coastal protection measures 
to mitigate damage from future natural disasters (Appendix 7). 
  
44.  Power. The tsunami completely disrupted the power supply system in at least 95 islands 
(about 48% of the islands with electricity) and left the population without electricity for days 
before the first teams arrived to restore temporary electric power. The needs assessment 
estimated the damage and the recovery needs of the power sector to be $4.6 million. The 
tsunami damaged 24 powerhouses, 104 generators with capacities ranging from 20 to 150 
kilowatts (kW), 34 switchboards, more than 121 km of cables of various sizes, 632 distribution 
boxes, and 652 streetlights. 
 
45.  The project component includes rehabilitation of the damaged power supply system. 
This will consist of supply and installation of new generators and distribution networks, including 
cables and distribution boxes. Streetlights will be installed if necessary. In bigger islands, with 
more than one generator, panel boards will be provided to synchronize operations. In islands 
where the powerhouse was badly damaged, new powerhouses will be constructed. Restoring 
connections to households will include installation of new meters and consumer panels. This 
work will restore facilities to pre-tsunami levels or to a higher disaster-resistant standard if this is 
more cost-effective in the long run (Appendix 8). 
 
46.  Fisheries. According to estimates by the Ministry of Fisheries, Agriculture, and Marine 
Resources (MFAMR), the total cost for repair and rehabilitation of the fisheries industry will be 
about $25 million.15 This covers repair and/or replacement of fishing vessels, engines, fishing 
gear and accessories, fish processing equipment, and infrastructure. Immediate assistance is 
needed by the fisheries sector to replace equipment and utensils lost by fish processors. The 
MFAMR has identified 128 islands where fish processors have been severely affected and the 
Project aims to support the fish processors by providing them with processing equipment, 
working capital, and extension services and by strengthening the MFAMR. ADB’s assistance is 
proposed to be $2.6 million, of which about 70% would be for equipment and basic inputs, about 
10%  for  working  capital,  and  the  balance  for  consultant  services,  training,  extension,  and 
administrative support. 
 
47.  The MFAMR, in conjunction with affected fish processors, will select, in a participatory 
manner, community-based organizations (CBOs) or island development centers (IDCs), who will 
be responsible for delivering Project inputs and working capital to the affected fish processors. 
The Project will provide CBOs or IDCs with training so they can provide efficient services to fish 
processors (Appendix 9). 
 
48.  Agriculture. The agriculture sector has been badly hit, as the tsunami waves caused 
temporary, semi-permanent, or permanent damage to soil and water. Destruction to standing 
crops, arable land and groundwater, loss of farming equipment, and damage to agriculture 
infrastructure have been substantial. Declines in production and yield levels of field and other 
crops,  including  homestead  cultivation  such  as  breadfruit,  mango  and  other  fruit  trees,  is 
significant.  The  needs  assessment  estimated  total  losses  to  be  about  $11.1  million.  The 
MFAMR has identified 42 islands where field crops were affected by the tsunami, and 26 islands 
where perennials and fruit trees were severely affected. The Project aims to support affected 
farmers in the perennial and field crop sectors by providing them with farm inputs, tools and 
equipment, and working capital in order to rehabilitate their farms and restore their livelihoods. 
                                                 
15 The joint needs assessment has estimated a lower figure of $14.1 million, which MFAMR regards as an 
underestimate.

12 
ADB’s assistance is proposed to be $2.5 million, of which about 70% would be for equipment 
and basic inputs, about 10% for working capital, and the balance for consultant services, 
training, extension, and administrative support.  
 
49.  MFAMR, in conjunction with affected fish processors, will select CBOs or IDCs to deliver 
project inputs and working capital to the affected farmers. MFAMR will verify the targeted 
farmers with assistance from atoll offices. In order to ensure effective use of project inputs, 
MFAMR will provide extension services to farmers through the three mobile extension service

G.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management and Coordination 
52.  Soon after the tsunami, the Government established a National Disaster Management 
Center (NDMC). The NDMC has been functioning as a central agency for (i) collecting and 
updating data on damage, and (ii) coordinating the Government’s relief efforts with support from 
international community. About 1 month after the disaster, on 31 January 2005, the Government 
adopted a long-term framework for the NDMC. It was considered important to continue the work 
of NDMC without interruption, but reorganize its work into two areas. The functions of NDMC 
will be assigned to a newly created National Economic Recovery and Reconstruction Program 
(NERRP). 
 
53.  Under this arrangement, NERRP's tasks will include (i) planning and implementation of 
the reconstruction and rehabilitation of affected islands, (ii) coordinating the recovery of the 
national economy, and (iii) planning and implementation of long-term projects within the national 
development framework. The NERRP consists of staff from MOFT (who will be handling the 
economic  recovery)  and  MPND  (who  will  be  dealing  with  housing  and  infrastructure 
reconstruction), and staff from other ministries. MOFT will be the executing agency of the 
Project, while its implementation will be centralized in the NERRP.  
 
54.  The Project will be implemented by a centralized project management unit (PMU) to be 
created under NERRP, so that the Government does not need to form a new and separate unit. 
MOFT  will,  however,  appoint  a  dedicated  project  manager  to  coordinate  and  oversee 
implementation,  who  will  be  supported  by  five  sections  under  NERRP  (planning  and 
programming, procurement, financial and accounting, monitoring and evaluation, and technical 
and implementation). The project manager and the NERRP’s five existing sections will be the 
PMU of the Project. The technical ministries and agencies will be the implementing agencies of 
the Project. They will assign their staff to the PMU under the technical and implementation 
section, and will be responsible for addressing technical matters in their respective areas of 
expertise, as follows: 
 
(i)  Ministry of Health (MOH) and Ministry of Environment and Construction (MEC) in 
the water supply, sanitation and solid waste management sector;

14 
 
(ii)  Ministry  of  Atolls  Development  (MOAD),  and  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Civil 
Aviation (MTCA) in the transport sector; 
 
(iii)  Ministry of Fisheries, Agriculture and Marine Resources (MFAMR), in agriculture 
and fisheries sectors; and 
 
(iv)  State Electricity Company Limited (STELCO) in power sector. 
 
55.  In addition, MOAD will support co-ordination of activities at the atolls level. 
 
56.  The  PMU  will  be  responsible  for  (i)  consolidating  subproject  proposals  from 
implementing agencies and submitting them for approval by the project coordinating committee 
(PCC, see below); (ii) preparing bidding documents and procuring civil works, equipment, goods 
and related services for infrastructure reconstruction; (iii) recommending the release of grant 
funds under working capital schemes to the affected communities; (iv) disbursing funds and 
carrying  out  accounting,  including  preparing  financial  reports;  (v)  preparing  and  submitting 
progress  reports  to  PCC  and  ADB;  and  (vi)  maintaining  the  website  for  the  Project.  The 
Government has agreed to establish the PMU and to appoint the project manager and key PMU 
staff by end-March 2005. 
 
57.  To ensure coordination, the PCC will be co-chaired by the Minister of Finance and 
Treasury and the Minister of Planning and National Development or their respective designates, 
and will include high-level representatives from MPND and the implementing agencies, as well 
as from the Ministry of Gender, Family Development and Social Security and the Department of 
External Resources. The PCC will guide the PMU on policy matters, and select high-priority 
subprojects proposed by the PMU. The PCC will meet as needed but not less than once every 
three months. The Project organization structure is in Appendix 12. 
 
58.  As part of the joint needs assessment, and in preparation for IDA credit and grant 
support,  the  World  Bank  has  completed  a  financial  management  assessment  of  the 
Government’s  implementation  arrangements  for  the  Tsunami  Relief  and  Reconstruction 
Program (TRRP); and the TRRF, through which the Government proposes to route all TRRP 
funds.  Based  on  the  assessment’s  recommendations,  the  Government  is  finalizing 
implementation arrangements in order to ensure transparency and efficient fiduciary controls. A 
sound financial management system, incorporating financial arrangements, control processes, 
and funds flow arrangements, is a requirement of the TRRP, and is being established and 
documented in the TRRF operations manual. Thus, while it is recognized that public financial 
management and accountability in the Maldives is at a relatively early stage, there is a strong 
understanding and commitment within the Government to modernize.  Important steps have 
already been taken to ensure that the financial management arrangements for the TRRP and 
the TRRF are able to account for project resources and reporting of project expenditures. 
 
59.  Project  Monitoring  and  Anticorruption  Measures.  ADB’s  EM  staff,  project 
consultants,  and  periodic  review  missions  will  closely  monitor  compliance  with  ADB’s 
requirements to ensure quality control, expeditious implementation of subprojects, and rapid 
assistance to MOFT on project implementation matters. The EM staff, consultants, and review 
missions will also closely monitor anticorruption measures undertaken by the PCC and PMU, 
carry out random checks on procurement, and on accounts of the Project and subprojects, and 
inspect facilities rehabilitated by the Project. The anticorruption measures adopted under the 
Project include (i) strict financial management with strengthened Government monitoring and

15 
independent monitoring by consultants; (ii) the use of detailed subproject selection criteria; 
(iii) strong  project  supervision  with  appropriate  consultancy  input;  (iv)  regular  independent 
performance auditing; and (v) random spot checks by EM staff, consultants, and ADB review 
missions.  
 
60.  In addition, the Government will involve CBOs, IDCs, and nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs) in monitoring project implementation. Consultants and the PMU will determine specific 
monitoring indicators for outputs of sectors and subprojects. The Government will establish a 
grievance mechanism within the existing Public Complaints Bureau to give tsunami-affected 
people an opportunity to be heard and an opportunity to submit their complaints related to 
ADB’s proposed assistance. Facilitation units will be established on each affected island to help 
individuals and communities to access goods and services financed under the Project, or other 
assistance. These units will be established in collaboration with CBOs and NGOs. The PMU will 
also publicly disclose information on procurement on the website for the Project. The website 
will  provide  information  on  financial  statements,  bidding  procedures,  bidders,  and  contract 
awards for the Project as well as the list of goods and services purchased and their intended 
and actual utilization. ADB’s EM staff and consultants will help to create and maintain such a 
website. 
 
2.  Subproject Selection Criteria and Approval 
61.  The implementing agencies, through the PMU, will propose a list of subprojects. The 
PMU will screen proposals and submit them to PCC for final selection. The Government and 
ADB have agreed that each subproject must satisfy the following criteria.  
 
(i)  It  should  rehabilitate  or  restore  tsunami-damaged  infrastructure  and  facilities 
based  on  the  needs  assessment,  and  will  exclude  relief  work  and  projects 
addressing long-term development needs.  
 
(ii)  It should be technically feasible and represent a least-cost alternative.  It should 
be financially viable, sustainable, and cost-effective, and incorporates disaster 
resistant features, where necessary and feasible; 
 
(iii)  It should, to the extent possible, involve local communities and beneficiaries in 
the selection, design, implementation, and operation and maintenance (O&M) as 
much as possible.  
 
(iv)  It can be completed within the project implementation period.  
 
(v)  It should not be financed by another agency.  
 
(vi)  It should have a direct social and economic impact (subprojects will be prioritized 
on this basis).  Priority will also be given to subprojects that rehabilitate ongoing 
or completed ADB financed projects.  
 
(vii)  It  should  comply  with  the  Government’s  environmental  requirements,  ADB’s 
Environment  Policy  (2002),  and  the  agreed  environmental  assessment 
framework.  For  subprojects  that  require  an  initial  environmental  examination 
(IEE),  the  IEE  should  be  included  in  the  subproject  proposal,  and  the 
Government’s environment clearance should be obtained before the contract is

16 
awarded. Any project deemed by ADB to be environmentally an ‘A’ category will 
not be eligible for ADB financing.   
 
(viii)  It  should  avoid  any  land  acquisition  or  involuntary  resettlement.  If, however,  
either  is  unavoidable  in  the  course  of  the  Project,  it  will  be  conducted  in 
accordance with the Government’s applicable laws and regulations, ADB’s Policy 
on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995),  and  the  agreed  resettlement  framework 
(Appendix 18) before the award of the subproject contract. 
 
62.  Subproject proposals will be prepared by the PMU in a format to be agreed by the 
Government  and  ADB.  The  PMU  will  be  responsible  for  the  preparation,  submission, 
implementation, and benefits monitoring and evaluation. The first subproject for each sector will 
be subject to prior review and approval by ADB before they begin. Each subsequent subproject 
costing more than $500,000 equivalent will be submitted to ADB for prior review and approval. 
The procedures for selection, approval, and implementation are in Appendix 13. 
 
3.  Implementation Schedule 
63.  As the Project is for emergency assistance, it will be implemented expeditiously after 
approval and completed in 24 months. For selected subprojects, performance indicators and 
time-bound completion schedules will be determined by the PMU in consultation with project 
consultants and EM staff. The detailed implementation schedule is in Appendix 14. 
 
4.  Procurement 
64.  Procurement of goods, services and works will be consistent with ADB’s Guidelines for 
Procurement, yet carried out expediently in order to meet the contemplated implementation 
schedule. ADB’s procedures for providing reconstruction assistance after disasters allow for 
considerable flexibility, so project activities can start promptly. Local procurement will be the 
preferred mode for all civil works because of the relatively short implementation period, the 
small  size  of  contract  packages,  and  the  wide  geographic  spread  of  the  project  sites. 
Community participation in procurement will be encouraged. 
 
65.  The procurement of goods and services, including equipment and materials, will follow 
international competitive bidding procedures when the estimated contract cost is more than 
$1 million equivalent, and international shopping when the estimated contract cost is up to 
$1 million equivalent. Bidding periods of 7–15 days for international shopping are acceptable. 
Procurement of goods and services below $100,000 may be undertaken by direct purchase, 
allowing for 3–5 days for submission of quotations. The procurement of commodities in bulk 
shall be undertaken under normal competitive commercial practices appropriate to the trade, 
and acceptable to ADB.  Contracts for such specific commodities shall not exceed $1 million. 
 
66.  None of the Project’s individual civil works contracts is expected to exceed $3 million. 
However, if contract packages are enlarged, civil works contracts with estimated values greater 
than $3 million will be procured in accordance with international competitive bidding procedures. 
Contracts with estimated values of $3 million or less will be procured in accordance with local 
competitive bidding procedures acceptable to ADB, and with bidding periods of 21–30 days.  
Small and simple civil works, estimated to cost $500,000 or less, may have a 15-day bidding 
period.  Pre-qualification  or  a  registration  system  (for  local  contractors)  will  be  used  as 
incorporated into the Government’s procurement procedures and documents. To encourage 
communities  to  participate  and  the  use  of  domestic  materials,  community  participation  in

17 
procurement will be pilot tested in the transport, fisheries and agriculture sectors.  Small works 
contracts with estimated costs of $50,000 or less may be awarded to community groups or 
organizations, in accordance with practices and procedures acceptable to ADB.  
 
67.  The procurement of goods, related services, and works through international shopping, 
local  competitive  bidding,  and  other  procurement  methods  will  follow  the  Government’s 
procurement procedures established for TRRF, if acceptable to ADB. Initial scrutiny suggests 
that the Government’s existing procedures and bidding documents are broadly in line with 
ADB’s requirements.16 For international shopping, local competitive bidding, direct purchase, 
and commodity procurements, post facto approval procedures will be followed. However, if ADB 
does not approve the award or terms of the contract, the Government will not use grant funds to 
finance the contract. If the grant funds have been used, the Government will refund to ADB any 
such payments. 
 
68.  Prior review by ADB of invitations for bids and bidding documents shall be required for 
procurement under international competitive bidding procedures.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACT, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic Benefits and Financial Sustainability 
79.  The selected subprojects will be technically feasible, cost-effective, and will represent 
least-cost alternatives.  If it is appropriate, they will upgrade the infrastructure so that similar 
catastrophes can be withstood and environmental standards can be met. A rapid economic 
assessment was undertaken based on available data and simplified assumptions for each 
Project  component—water  supply  and  sanitation  and  solid  waste  management,  transport, 
power; fisheries and agriculture.  The Project’s weighted average economic internal rate of 
return (EIRR) is estimated to be 19%. 
 
80.  A broad assessment of financial viability and sustainability of each project component 
has been made, based on available data and simplified assumptions.  During implementation, 
the PMU and the PCC will evaluate the financial sustainability of the subprojects by ensuring 
that the Government has sufficient resources to meet future recurrent costs. The ADF loan 
funds  will  not  represent  a  significant  debt  burden  for  the  Government,  since  they  are 
reallocations  of  loan  savings  from  ongoing  projects,  which  had  been  factored  in  by  the 
Government in its debt service commitments.  The funds will be channeled through TRRF, for 
which adequate fiduciary controls will be established, and ADB subprojects will be screened by 
the PMU and PCC. This will ensure that the funds will be used for the intended purposes and 
that Project benefits will be realized.  
 
B.  Poverty and Other Impacts 
81.  Poverty Impact. The Project will contribute to the Government’s efforts to regenerate 
the economy, rehabilitate the public infrastructure and public utilities, generate livelihoods and 
employment, and create social cohesion. It will help restore access to public infrastructure and

20 
services. It will help to maintain clean living conditions through community-based water supply, 
sanitation and solid waste management programs. The Project will also help re-establish lost 
agricultural and fishing incomes through livelihood programs targeted at agricultural and fishing 
individuals,  especially  women  who  engage  in  home  gardening  and  fish  processing.  The 
interventions proposed within each sector will help restore the livelihoods of many tsunami-
affected  and  internally  displaced  people.  The  priority  given  to  providing  unskilled  work  to 
affected people, including women, will be an important intervention for people who cannot re-
establish their livelihoods and are living in temporary shelters. The Project will help to restore 
the confidence and dignity of people and communities affected by the tsunami. A summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 16.   
 
C.  Environmental Impacts 
82.  The Project is classified as category B, in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy 
(2002).17 An IEE was conducted to identify potential impacts. It showed that no significant 
adverse environmental impacts were foreseen and therefore a full-scale environmental impact 
assessment was unlikely to be required. The IEE focused on potential impacts associated with 
rehabilitation and reconstruction of maritime transport and protection structures, rehabilitation of 
community  power  supply  schemes  and  community  electrification  services,  sewage  and 
sanitation  systems,  solid  waste  management,  and  the  provision  of  working  capital  for

D.  Resettlement Issues 
83.  The tsunami displaced more than 12,500 people from their islands and destroyed more 
than 4,000 houses. Homeless people are living temporarily in makeshift public shelters or with 
relatives and host families. The Government's policy on "resettlement of population displaced or 
affected by the Tsunami" stresses that the relocation of displaced households will be a voluntary 
process which will be carried out in consultation and agreement with the households as well as 
their  host  communities,  if  any.  It  emphasizes  that  Government  will  inform  all  relocating 
households of their entitlements: compensation for damaged houses and lost assets, relocation 
allowance, transitional support and development assistance, and access to ‘socioeconomic 
services and utilities’. On an island that is habitable and safe after the tsunami, each internally 
displaced household will receive compensation for its lost dwelling and other structures to 
enable them to be reconstructed or repaired at their original location. If the original location is 
severely eroded or difficult to reclaim, the household will receive a new plot of land on the same 
island to construct its house and other structures. Alternatively, the household may apply for 
permanent resettlement on a ”focus/safe” island. Applications for such permanent resettlement 
may be made by an individual household or an entire island community. Households that are 
living temporarily on ‘safe’ islands after the tsunami may apply for permanent resettlement on 
”focus/safe” islands. These islands will become self-reliant in emergency management, with an 
early warning system, well-built jetties and harbors, and improved communications facilities. 
They will be regional centers where economic growth is expected. On islands made unsafe by 
the tsunami, each household will be encouraged, but not forced, to relocate to a “focus/safe”

E.  Risks 
85.  A potential risk is that, despite strong Government commitment, implementation could be 
hampered by slow approval procedures and lack of adequate capacity in the implementing 
agencies. Time-consuming approval procedures and slow implementation are the two main 
concerns. Based on detailed discussions with the Government, ADB’s assessment is that the 
Government is strongly committed to the timely and effective completion of the Project. The 
Government has streamlined approval procedures for all projects related to reconstruction and 
economic  recovery.  Furthermore,  to  ensure  coordination,  a  project  coordinating  committee 
(PCC) will be established. The PCC will have the highest level of political commitment and will 
be co-chaired by the Minister of Finance and Treasury and the Minister of Planning and National 
Development or their respective designates, and will include high-level representatives from 
MPND and the implementing agencies, as well as the Ministry of Gender, Family Development 
and Social Security and Department of External Resources. The PCC will provide guidance to 
the PMU on policy matters, and will select high-priority subprojects proposed by the PMU. The 
selected IAs have considerable experience in implementing ADB-financed projects and are 
familiar  with  ADB  procedures.  Specialized  consultancy  inputs  will  provide  additional 
implementation assistance to the PMU and the IAs. The Government’s contribution to the 
Project will be in the form of exemption of taxes and duties, and administrative support during 
the 2-year implementation period of the Project.  
 
86.  Governance-related issues, including corruption, constitute another risk. These issues 
will be addressed by detailed subproject selection criteria, transparent implementation and 
monitoring mechanisms, and specific financial controls, including regular and random audits.

the EM and ADB headquarters staff. Random procurement and annual performance auditing at 
the executing agency level will also be carried out. In addition, the newly established NERRP 
will have specialized units to deal specifically with planning and programming; finance and 
accounting; procurement; technical issues and implementation; and monitoring and evaluation. 
A project manager will help to select and implement subprojects. The Government will establish 
a grievance mechanism to give tsunami-affected people an opportunity to be heard and submit

SUMMARY OF NEEDS ASSESSMENT 
1.  The tsunami which hit the Maldives on 26 December 2004 caused severe damage to the 
physical infrastructure of many islands.  
2.  Immediately  following  the  tsunami,  the  Government  of  Maldives  (the  Government) 
contacted  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  World  Bank,  requesting  them  to 
undertake  a  joint  assessment  of  the  tsunami  damage  and  recovery  needs.  A  joint  needs 
assessment mission began work on 5 January 2005. The United Nations also participated in the 
mission, along with the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC). A follow-up mission on 
1–4 February 2005 finalized the assessment, revising the initial estimates based on new data 
and  extensive  comments  received  from  the  Government  and  other  stakeholders.  The 
Government endorsed the findings of the report on 6 February 2005. 
A.  Estimated Damage and Financing Needs 
3.  The  tsunami  had  a  serious  impact  on  the  Maldives  by  inflicting  extensive  physical 
damage,  loss  of  life  and  livelihoods,  and  displacement  of  people.  The  current  displaced 
population is estimated to be about 12,500. About 6,700 people are internally displaced in their 
original islands and about 5,800 are displaced on other islands. Eighty-three people have died 
and twenty-five are still missing feared dead. Out of the 199 inhabited islands of the Maldives, 
13 islands were severely impacted with total destruction, 56 islands sustained major physical 
damage, and 121 islands moderate damage due to flooding.  Severe damage was caused to 
houses, tourist resorts, boats and other fishing equipment, schools, health facilities, transport 
and communication equipment, water and sanitation, and electricity infrastructure. There has 
also been substantial damage to agricultural crops and perennial trees. Farms, homestead 
plots,  and  aquifers  have  been  salinized.  The  physical  damage  has  led  to  severe  human 
suffering  and  large  segments  of  the  population  have  lost  their  dwellings,  lifetime  assets, 
savings, and sources of livelihood. Many displaced families are now living in temporary shelters 
or with relatives.  
4.  Total damages are estimated to be about $470 million, close to 62% of GDP (Table 
A2.1). About $298 million of these are direct damages; $172 million are indirect losses. The cost 
of direct damages is about 8% of the replacement cost of the entire national capital stock, 
estimated to be about $3.8 billion at 2004 prices. The tourism sector has incurred the largest 
direct damages, with losses estimated at $100 million (of which half is insured), followed by the 
housing sector with losses close to $65 million.  
5.  The largest indirect losses also occurred in the tourism sector, which has seen a sharp 
drop in tourist arrivals (as of end-January 2005, around 6,000 tourists are in the Maldives as 
compared with more than 16,000 at the same time last year).

because of the need to rebuild to higher standards to reduce vulnerability (e.g. housing) and 
because current construction or environmental standards are higher than when original facilities 
were built (e.g. sanitation), or because modern equipment or supplies are of higher quality and 
provide improved services (e.g. health, education). Some of the indirect losses cannot be 
recovered: production losses from fishing and agriculture, and tourism cancellations cannot be 
restored. The financing needs have been divided into short-term and long-term needs. The

8.  Education. Damages in the education sector range from damaged school infrastructure 
to insufficient teaching staff (because some expatriate teachers left). Thirty-seven percent of the 
schools  require  varying  degrees  of  repair  and  rehabilitation.  Six  have  been  completely

destroyed. Replacement of provisions for the affected schoolchildren is an immediate priority, 
along  with  the  repair  and  rehabilitation  of  damaged  school  facilities  and  construction  of 
temporary additional classrooms. The cost is estimated to be $21.1 million.  
9.  Health and Nutrition. Critical emergency needs such as safe drinking water, food, and 
emergency medicines are in place in the affected islands. People who lost their homes have 
been provided temporary shelters, and people reporting major injuries have been promptly 
attended  to.  The  critical  challenge  now  is  to  sustain  these  inputs  until  more  permanent

10.  Housing. Private housing suffered severe damage. The wave damaged structural and

1,847 houses totally destroyed and 3,500 partially damaged. For the houses to be built anew, 
the Government has proposed a two-stage housing reconstruction plan. In the first stage, a 
basic dwelling unit will be constructed. In the second stage, financial incentives will be provided 
for households to extend, modify, or improve the basic unit. Reconstruction costs are estimated 
at $74 million.  
11.  Fisheries. Because of the tsunami, 120 fishing vessels were lost or totally destroyed, 50 
fishing vessels were partially damaged or lost equipment, 5 reef fishing boats lost equipment, 16 
ocean cages were lost, 374 fish processors lost equipment, and 8 boatsheds and 2 fishery 
institutes were damaged. The estimated recovery cost for the damaged or lost vessels and 
provision of necessary equipment is $14.1 million. 
12.  Agriculture. The tsunami damaged field crops in 2,103 farms; destroyed backyard 
crops and agricultural tools in 11,678 homesteads; and damaged more than 700,000 fruit trees 
and 840,000 timber trees in inhabited islands. The damage to land and groundwater resources 
is  severe  in  35  agricultural  islands,  and  saline  water  intrusion  has  affected  112  inhabited 
islands. Recovery needs are estimated at $11.1 million. The reestablishment of the agricultural 
crops will involve improvement of soil, forestry, and water resources, importation of planting 
material, and provision of extension services, some of which will have to be obtained from other 
countries.  
13.  Water  Supply,  Sanitation  and  Solid  Waste  Management.  Preliminary  estimates 
suggest the potential loss of up to 1,000 community rainwater tanks, 6,000 household rainwater 
tanks and 20,000 m3 of rainwater supplies. Roof water harvesting piping and gutter systems 
have also been damaged, affecting an estimated 5,000 households. Up to 850 well pumps are 
estimated to have been lost as a result of flooding. In addition, the quality of groundwater 
supplies in 36 islands may have been compromised due to saline and sewage contamination. In 
addition, it is estimated that an approximate 5,000 toilets and 3,500 septic tanks may need to be 
provided, while there is also small bore sewer loss in highly affected areas. Recovery needs are 
estimated at $45.6 million. 
14.  Tourism. The impact from the tsunami is significant for both the private and public 
sectors. Direct damage to the tourism infrastructure and other related businesses is estimated 
at over $100 million, some of which will be covered by insurance. More significant is the loss of 
revenue from the downturn in tourist arrivals. The loss in total tourism receipts is estimated at 
$130 million. The key to minimizing the financial impact is to bring tourists back as quickly as

32   Appendix 2 
possible. This requires marketing focusing on the travel trade and potential tourists with the 
message that the tourism sector is operating normally, that most resorts were unaffected, that it 
is safe to visit the Maldives, and that visitors are welcome.  
15.  Transportation and Communications. The damage to transport and communication 
infrastructure (harbors, jetties, causeways, navigational aids, airports, telecoms) was less than 
originally feared. About 4,200 m length of quay wall, and 15,000 m of harbor or sea walls and 
breakwaters have been damaged or destroyed.  Dredging will be needed to remove about 
370,000 m3 tsunami-inflicted siltation. Five causeways have been partly damaged. While the 
telecommunications sector initially completely failed, all connections were restored by 7 January 
2005. It is estimated that about one third of navigation aids were damaged or destroyed. 
Recovery costs will amount to about $27 million. 
16.  Power. The tsunami damaged the electric power supply system in 95 islands (about 
48% of the islands with electricity) and there was no electricity for several days. The damaged 
facilities include: 24 power houses, 104 generators, 652 streetlights, 34 switchboards, 632 
distribution boxes, and more than 121 kilometers of cables. The Government is planning to 
restore the electricity supply systems in all affected islands to pre-tsunami levels. The recovery 
needs amount to $4.65 million, covering the installation of new equipment. 
17.  Public Administration. A preliminary assessment of damages is $50 million. However, 
further assessments of the damage to public offices such as island offices and courts may be 
needed. Repair of public offices is vital to enable them to function effectively in support of the 
recovery efforts. 
D.  External Financing Needs 
18.  The government provided swift relief to the affected islands and is now engaged in 
planning and executing a reconstruction program. However, it faces a financing gap estimated 
at $364 million, so external finance has been sought.  At the end of February, total commitments 
of cash assistance amounted to $61.6 million, of which $25.7 million has been received. The 
World Bank has provided $14 million in a mixture of grants and credits. The Government of 
Japan has committed $20 million of grants. However, it is clear that foreign financing received or 
pledged so far falls far short of the estimated reconstruction needs.

MACROECONOMIC IMPACT 
 
A.  Macroeconomic Performance Before the Tsunami 
 
1.  The Maldives achieved a robust annual average real gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth of 7.2% over 1997–2003 and graduated from least developed country (LDC) status in 
December 2004.  
 
2.  The Maldives’ most important economic sector is tourism, which in 2003 accounted for 
33% of GDP and grew by 15% in that year. Other important sectors include transport and 
communications  (14%  of  GDP),  manufacturing  (8%  of  GDP)  and  fisheries  (7%  of  GDP). 
Sustained  growth  in  tourism  stimulated  growth  in  construction,  transportation  and 
communications, and wholesale and retail trade. Despite a modest share of around 3% of GDP, 
agriculture is important to the island economies because it supplies food security and provides 
employment—particularly for women in the remote atolls. 
3.  The Maldives is an open economy because it needs to import almost everything except 
fish products, and to earn foreign exchange from tourism and fish products to finance its 
imports. The Maldives' fundamental reliance on the two export sectors—tourism and fisheries—
makes it highly vulnerable to internal and external shocks.  
 
4.  Over the period 1999–2004, the Maldives has run an average budget deficit of 4.3% of 
GDP.  Both  current  and  capital  expenditures  have  been  rising  since  1999.  Several 
developments,  including  the  high  priority  given  to  human  development—particularly  for 
community programs, social security, and welfare—and the sharp increase in housing and 
infrastructure, explain the recent jump in current and capital expenditures. On the revenue side, 
the tax to GDP ratio has been stagnant over the past 4 years. The Maldives’ fiscal revenue is 
based primarily on import duties, income from tourism, dividends from state-owned enterprises, 
and resort lease rents. In addition to its own budgetary resources, the Maldives has benefited 
from bilateral grants, although since 2001 revenue from grants has been declining. 
 
5.  The Government’s revenue stream is highly vulnerable to external factors. Tourism tax 
collection depends on the number of tourists. Bilateral grants steadily diminished from 4.5% of 
GDP in 1996 to 1.4% of GDP in 2003. Before 2003, the fiscal deficit was automatically financed 
from the ways and means account (WMA) at the Maldives Monetary Authority (MMA). Starting 
from 2004, the Government adopted a policy of not resorting to automatic financing of the deficit 
from the WMA. Inflation has remained low in recent years, ranging from –3% to 3%. Inflation in 
2003 was –2.9%, compared with 0.9% in 2002. This is the lowest inflation rate in 12 years. 
Public debt has continued to grow and reached the equivalent of 46.5% of GDP in 2003. Public 
external debt amounted to 30% of GDP in 2003.  
 
6.  Exports and imports grew rapidly during 2003. The current account deficit widened as 
growth in imports exceeded growth in exports. With a large capital account surplus, the overall 
balance of payments improved from a deficit of $21.4 million in 2001 to a surplus of $74.3 
million in 2003. Reserves currently amount to about $200 million. Bearing in mind the openness 
of the economy, the amount of short-term external debt, and the potential for capital flight by 
residents, reserves are relatively low.
