B.  The Macroeconomic Impact of the Tsunami 
7.  The Maldives was the only country where the effects of the tsunami were felt across the 
country, rather than in certain parts or regions. It is among the worst-affected countries and will 
probably face the highest per capita reconstruction costs. The tsunami has severely affected 
such key economic sectors as tourism, fisheries, and agriculture, and essential infrastructure 
like water supply, sanitation and power, the effects of which will spill over to other sectors. Given 
the scale of the damage (estimated at 62% of 2004 GDP) and the fragile fiscal situation, even 
before the tsunami, considerable external assistance will be needed for the economy to recover. 
 
1.  Economic Impact per Sector 
8.  The negative publicity following the tsunami has led to a steep decline in tourism. The 
disaster occurred in the period of peak occupancy rates, well above 90% (for a total of 16,100 
operational beds). The occupancy rate at the end of January 2005 was around 45% (for a total 
of 12,800 operational beds). 
 
9.  Tourism is expected to return to normal levels in the long run, as the chance of another 
tsunami is perceived as slight. The recovery in tourism activity will also depend on the speed 
with which the infrastructure (airports, jetties, hotels, harbours and roads) can be rehabilitated or 
reconstructed. Repairs to some resorts may take up to 1 year. The tourism sector is likely to 
experience a 25% decline in 2005 relative to 2004. 
 
10.  Activity in wholesale and retail trade, transport and communications will be affected by 
the decline in tourism.  
 
11.  Damage in the fisheries sector is compounded by the loss of harbors, jetties, and 
vessels. About 120 fishing vessels were completely destroyed and 50 more partially damaged. 
Damage to fish stocks and reefs was limited. No growth in fisheries is anticipated in 2005. 
 
12.  Agricultural crops were swept away and most agricultural land was covered with salty 
mud,  leaving  it  temporarily  unusable.  As  a  result  of  the  destruction  (combined  with  lower 
demand from resorts), the agriculture sector is likely to contract by about 5% in 2005. 
 
13.  A number of sectors are, however, expected to experience higher growth as a result of 
reconstruction in the wake of the tsunami. This is the case for coral and sand mining and 
construction. 
 
2.  Economic Growth 
14.  The combined impact of the tsunami will decelerate GDP growth substantially. Economic 
growth forecasts for 2005 have been revised downwards form the pre-tsunami estimate of 7.5% 
to 1%.  
 
3.  Government Financing 
15.  The impact of the tsunami on public finances is likely to be substantial. The effects 
include a reduction in revenues resulting from a lower tax base in combination with an increase 
in both current and capital expenditures.

Appendix 3  35 
16.  On the revenue side, government receipts from the tourism bed-night tax, and duties on 
tourism-related imports are likely to fall significantly. In addition, the government has decided to 
waive import duties on all tsunami-related imports. Increased grant receipts mitigate some of the 
decline in other government revenues. External grants in 2005 are expected to increase to 7.2% 
of GDP compared to the projected 1% pre-tsunami estimate.  
 
17.  On  the  expenditure  side,  reconstruction  and  rehabilitation  efforts  will  considerably 
increase public expenditure. Government expenditure is expected to increase from 42% of GDP 
to 54%. The budget deficit (including grants) is expected to rise from a projected 4% of GDP to 
10.5% of GDP. The budget deficit, excluding grants, would amount to 17.8% of GDP. 
 
18.  These figures raise concern over the sustainability of the deficit and how it will be 
financed. Given the limited manoeuvring space for the government as a result of continued 
deficit spending in the recent past, there is a danger that reconstruction spending will be 
constrained by a lack of financing. 
 
4.  External Accounts 
19.  The external balance is also expected to worsen, the contributing factors being the 
slowdown in tourism, and an increase in imports necessary for reconstruction. This comes in 
addition to an expected decrease in exports from the garments industry following the phase out 
of the Multi-Fiber Arrangement. However, increases in both official transfers and remittances 
are mitigating factors. Overall, the current account deficit is expected to rise sharply to about 
23% of GDP. The deficit in the balance of payments is likely to be about $68 million in 2005, 
after adjustments for a substantial increase in expected external assistance. 
 
5.  Employment 
20.  Before the tsunami, tourism employed almost 40% of the labor force. So far most resorts 
have chosen not to dismiss any workers, who continue to be paid, although some have been 
temporarily reassigned to resorts abroad. Fisheries accounted for another 11% of the labor 
force, and this sector has been badly affected by the loss of fishing vessels, equipment, and by 
the erosion of agricultural lands. A number of small-scale programs that provide cash for work, 
such as brick-making, have been begun by NGOs to provide some affected people with a 
temporary income. Quotas on the inflow of foreign workers have been temporarily lifted because 
of the need for labor for reconstruction. Before the tsunami, the Government had started the 
development of a retraining program for the unemployed and this may need to be implemented 
more rapidly.  
 
C.  Mitigating the Economic Downturn 
21.  Key measures to mitigate the adverse macroeconomic impacts of the tsunami include: 
 
(i)  Income support to the affected population, for example as is being done through 
cash transfers. This also helps to maintain liquidity in the atolls. 
(ii)  Support for affected populations so they can restore their livelihoods by financing 
the replacement of key assets and tools and employing local labor in rebuilding 
infrastructure. 
(iii)  Encouraging a resumption in tourism activity by conveying a clear message to 
the rest of the world that (a) key infrastructure, like the airport, is safe and

functioning normally, and (b) the impact of the tsunami on most resorts was 
minor and they are open for business.  
(iv)  Ensuring that the reconstruction effort is consistent with macroeconomic stability 
over the medium term, by containing the fiscal deficit, adopting an appropriate 
exchange rate policy, and preserving price stability. 
 
D.  Financing Relief and Reconstruction 
22.  Significant external financing is needed, in the form of grants and concessional loans to 
the government, as well as higher inflows of private funds, to finance the budget and the 
widening current account deficit of the balance of payments. External finance has been sought. 
As of the end of February, total commitments of cash assistance amounted to $61.6 million from 
bilateral, UN, and private sources. The World Bank has provided $14 million in mixed grants 
and credits and the IMF $6.3 million in emergency assistance. The Government of Japan has 
committed $20 million in grants. However, foreign financing received or pledged so far falls far 
short of the estimated needs. 
 
23.  It needs to be emphasized that the terms on which external finance is available will 
determine the pace of reconstruction. Indeed, in undertaking additional external liability for post-
tsunami rehabilitation and reconstruction, the Government will need to be particularly careful in 
not running up external debt stocks to uncomfortable levels, which could impact future growth 
prospects.  
 
24.  In addition to the government, it is anticipated that the private sector will increase foreign 
borrowings, in order to finance bank liquidity and the reconstruction of resorts. Such borrowings 
could sharply raise total external debt. Hence, as much as possible grants will be the preferred 
mode of external assistance to finance post-tsunami rehabilitation and reconstruction.

TSUNAMI RELIEF AND RECONSTRUCTION FUND 
 
1.  The Government of the Maldives (the Government) has set up a Tsunami Relief and 
Reconstruction Fund (TRRF) under the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT). The TRRF 
will manage all resources received from international and local sources in cash or in kind, and 
will channel all resources to programmed relief and reconstruction activities. The TRRF will 
operate as a separate fund within the budget framework of the Government, and will enable the 
Government to transparently delineate and account for tsunami-related assistance and ensure 
effective  use  of  funds.  The  Government’s  objectives  for  establishing  the  TRRF  are:  (i)  to 
significantly reduce the risk of delays in the availability of funds at the operational level; (ii) to 
enable disbursement of funds in a timely manner for smooth implementation; (iii) to replenish 
the account quickly to maintain program momentum; and (iv) to increase the speed, accuracy 
and transparency of reporting. The Government has requested that donors provide as much of 
their funding as possible through the TRRF to: (i) assure transparency and harmonization, (ii) 
eliminate duplication of efforts, and (iii) reduce administrative overheads. 
 
2.  A needs assessment, recently completed for the Government by a joint team from World 
Bank, ADB, and the UN, estimated the total public financing needs for reconstruction at about 
$304 million. Of this, approximately one third is required to meet immediate reconstruction 
needs for the first 6 months. The remaining is required to meet medium-term reconstruction 
needs—from 6 months to 36 months. Total commitments reported by the Government as of  the 
end of February 2005 are around $61.6 million, of which $25.7 million has been received. The 
Government anticipates that all tsunami reconstruction assistance will be managed under the 
TRRF. Total cash and in kind receipts as of end February 2005 amount to about $68 million

A.  Damage and Impact 
1.  While much progress had been made over the past decade throughout the Maldives in 
providing water and storage through rainwater tank programs, investment in sanitation and solid 
waste management has been more limited. This has resulted in deteriorating living conditions 
on many inhabited islands. Impacts resulting from the absence of basic infrastructure and 
environmental services in the atolls was further exacerbated by the damage following the high 
waves and flooding of the Indian Ocean tsunami which hit the Maldives on 26 December 2004, 
leading  in  some  cases  to  absolute  destruction  of  existing  infrastructure.  The  sector  was 
seriously affected: whilst provision of water supply and basic sanitation services are in urgent 
need of replacement, rehabilitation or reconstruction, the need to expedite adequate solid waste 
management practices and structuring the sector for efficient operation emerged as critical to 
cope with damage and debris. 
 
2.  Water supply in the atolls is almost entirely provided through a combination of rainwater 
tanks (both household and communal), which are the principal source of drinking water and 
groundwater extraction through domestic wells, commonly utilized for washing and bathing. 
Damages include loss of all water supplies, household and communal rainwater tanks, damage 
to roof water harvesting piping and gutter systems and well pumps. The extent of damage to the 
sanitation and sewerage network will require a detailed assessment before prioritization. In 
extensively affected areas a significant number of toilets and septic tanks need replacing, or 
when the structures remain undamaged desludging is required, whilst small bore sewer and 
outfall loss is estimated to be as large as 126 km and 2.4 km, respectively. The joint ADB, UN 
and World Bank Needs Assessment Mission estimated the recovery needs to be $45 million. 
 
B.  Scope 
 
3.  This component will rehabilitate and provide water supply, sanitation and solid waste 
management  infrastructure  and  services  for  the  69  most  affected  islands  communities.1 
Rehabilitation works will be carried out to restore facilities to pre-tsunami level or to a higher 
cost-effective environmentally-acceptable standard. The Project will be divided into two phases:

1.  Due  to  the  archipelagic  nature  of  its  topography,  the  Maldivian  transport  sector  is 
maritime and airborne based with few paved roads in Malé (60km), on Laamu and Addu Atolls 
(14 km each) and the rest of unknown lengths of compacted coral village roads including of 
about 250 km of such roads under maintenance of the Ministry of Construction and Public 
Works. 
 
2.  Domestic transport of freight and passengers is predominantly by sea. As there are no 
significantly large regional centers in the Maldives, transport between Malé and individual small 
island communities dominates domestic maritime freight and passenger traffic. In this regard, 
Malé-to-outer islands traffic is almost entirely import cargo transshipped at Malé Port. Heavy 
congestion prevails at the inter-atoll harbor in Malé. Maritime transport services between Malé 
and the outer islands, and within and between the outer atolls, are inadequate and often 
unreliable. Inter-atoll and inter-island shipping services are operated entirely by the private 
sector, while the Government provides essential infrastructure such as ports and protected 
island harbors, and regulatory functions like maritime safety administration. Aside from the main 
port in Malé, the country has about 90 manmade protected island harbors with quays, basins 
and breakwaters; several natural harbors; jetties and approach channels to access the 200 
inhabited islands. However, most of the islands are lacking proper transport infrastructure. 86 
nos.  “12-miles  light  beacons,”  209  nos.  “2-miles  reef  markers”  and  390  “harbor  entrance 
markers” mark the inter-atoll and inter-island shipping routes. 
 
3.  The  airport  sector  consists  of  1  international  airport  and  3  regional  airports  in  the 
southern and one in the northern atolls. 
 
B.  Damage and Impact of the Tsunami 
 
4.  While the 26 December Tsunami inflicted severe physical damage to housing, power 
facilities,  agriculture  and  fisheries,  the  damage  to  the  transport  infrastructure  was  less  in 
comparison than originally feared. This can largely be attributed to the facts that ports and 
maritime facilities are generally located at the inner side of the atolls, away from the direct 
tsunami impact and that the airports are located on islands where the tsunami had limited 
impact, like for example in Malé and Gan islands where the most substantial port and airport 
infrastructure is located. 
 
5.  It is estimated that about one third of the navigation aids were damaged or destroyed. 
About 36 jetties are reported to have some damage. About 4,200 m length of quay walls, and 
15,000 length of harbor/sea walls and breakwaters have been damaged or destroyed, and 
about 370,000 m3 of dredging will be required to remove tsunami-inflicted siltation of harbor 
basis  and  approach  channels.  Five  causeways,  which  are  very  important  for  inter-island 
connection, have been partly damaged.  
 
6.  There  are  also  some  damages  to  Malé  Commercial  Harbor  and  Malé  International 
Airport, part of which will be covered by insurance. However, appropriate safety operation of the 
airport requires a short-term intervention. Tsunami-related damage in Malé International Airport 
includes  airfield  area  and  drainage  works,  sea  wall  defenses,  navigation  equipment  and 
communications equipment.

B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
The Maldives has experienced rapid economic growth over the past 25 years. Gross domestic product (GDP) 
maintained an average annual growth of about 9% per year primarily due to the development and expansion of 
tourism, fisheries, and service industry. However, geographical challenges have led to unbalanced economic growth 
and poverty in the country. With a population of about 300 thousand people, the Maldives is an archipelago that 
consists of about 1,192 islands spread across 860 km. Regional disparities can be seen in terms of absolute 
poverty, and social and physical development. An estimated 70% of the population outside of Malé has an income 
equivalent to the bottom 20% in Malé (VPA 1998). The cost of providing infrastructure and quality services remains 
high and ineffective due to a dispersed population and the remoteness of some islands. Global warming also 
threatens many islands in the Maldives, as most are located just above sea level. A lack of infrastructure, social 
services, and rising sea levels fuels migration to Malé.  
 
Pre-tsunami, absolute poverty under the poverty line of Rf15 per person per day decreased from 43% in 1997 to 
about 22% in 2004, based on preliminary results of the Vulnerability and Poverty Assessment (VPA) 2004 data.1 As 
a result of the Tsunami on 26 December 2004, absolute poverty is likely to increase the number of poor below the 
poverty line of Rf15 per person per day. The Tsunami significantly damaged about 39 islands, of which about 14 
islands were completely destroyed. About 100 thousand of the population was severely affected. About 7% of the 
population has been displaced—close to 12,000 people have been displaced from their islands, and another 8,500 
people are temporarily relocated to other places on their own island. The Ministry of Gender, Family Development, 
and Social Security is providing emergency cash payments of Rf1,500, Rf1,000 and Rf500 per person based on the 
level of damage caused by the tsunami on housing structure. Public infrastructure and services were damaged and 
disrupted (i.e., ports and harbors, power supply, and water supply). Livelihoods and service jobs were also affected, 
as many rely on tourism and fishing industries. For instance, about 18% of the total labor force is engaged in 
primary fishing activities, but almost 98% of employment in the fisheries sector is found in the atolls (VPA 1998). 
Damaged infrastructure systems pose serious environmental and health risks and inhibit social and economic 
development of individuals living in 20 administrative atolls. The estimated cost of tsunami-related damages is about 
$470 million (about 60% of the GDP), of which about $298 million are for direct damages.  
 
The Project will help restore access to public infrastructure and services. It will help maintain clean living conditions 
through community-based water supply, sanitation and solid waste management programs. The Project will also 
help re-establish lost agricultural and fishing incomes through livelihood programs targeted at agricultural and 
fishing individuals. Interventions proposed within each sector will help restore the livelihoods of many tsunami-
affected and internally displaced people. By reducing the risk of vulnerability, the Project will also help to restore 
confidence levels and self-dignity of people and communities adversely affected by the tsunami.

D.  Gender Development 
Malidivian women make up close to 49% of the total population, and close to 52% of the tsunami-affected 
population in 20 atolls. Female-headed households make up about 46% of the total number of households due to 
marital status, or absentee husband that migrated for work and/or were absent at the time of the census. There are 
no visible gender disparities in the provision of basic health care and education. Over the last 30 years, literacy rate 
of females aged 15 and above reached 97%. Maternal mortality rate per 100,000 live births reduced from 480 in 
1990 to 75 in 2000. However, gender disparities are found in some areas such as levels of nutritional intake, school 
performance and educational attainment levels. For example, anemia affects about 51% of the female population 
and indirectly contributes to maternal mortality. 
 
Women play important roles in economic activities, and are responsible for a variety of domestic tasks. They often 
engage in home gardening of agricultural products (i.e., curry leaves, fruits, and vegetables), and in fish processing. 
These items may be kept for home-use, given to others free of charge, or sold to a middleman for sale in another 
island market. Women also hold government positions, with some representation at high levels: two women are 
members of the cabinet (i.e., Ministry of Health and Ministry of Gender, Family Development and Social Security), 
and one is an atoll leader. A gender policy for the Maldives has been formulated and is in the process of being 
approved. Women also participate in community affairs and in the island’s women’s committee.  
 
About 4% of all employees in tourism are women. A shift to a service-oriented economy has caused more women to 
enter the labor work force. According the World Bank-ADB-UN systems joint needs assessment, labor force 
participation rate (LFPR) for women rose by 9% from 1995 to 2000. Even with this increase there is considerable

C.  Description of the Environment 
 
  1.   Physical Resources 
 
3.  The 1,192 low-lying coral islands of the Maldives archipelago extend over 26 atolls 
covering an area of 115,300 square kilometers (km2). The islands stretch over a distance of 860 
kilometers (km) north to south, and 130 km east to west. The average area of the 199 inhabited 
islands is 57.8 hectares (ha) and only 3 islands exceed an area of 400 ha. The maximum 
elevation is below 3 meters (m) above mean sea level and most (80%) of the land is less than 
1m above mean high tide level. Thirteen of the atolls lie within the three Central Regions. Inside 
the  atolls,  water  depth  is  generally  less  than  80  m.  The  islands  comprise  layers  of 
unconsolidated shell and coral sand and debris, lying on coral rock, which are normally less 
than 10 m below the surface. Soils are thin (20 centimeters or less) freely draining and highly 
alkaline. There is abundant calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus; and sufficient iron. The 
tropical climate is dominated by two monsoon periods. Temperature ranges between 25-30 
degrees Celsius, and rainfall is about 2000 millimeters per annum. Water on the islands occurs 
almost entirely as groundwater within the aquifer that overlies the coral rock.   
   
  2.   Ecological Resources 
 
4.  The Maldives displays a pristine marine environment. The well being of the coral reef, 
the 7th largest in the world covering a total area of 8,920 km2 and contributing to 5% of the 
world’s reef area, is of concern at national and international levels. Marine biological diversity is 
exceptional  and  is  considered  to  be  one  of  the  world’s  richest  ecosystems.  Most  recent 
accounts recognize 187 species of stony coral, 1,090 species of fish, and almost 300 species of 
marine algae, 36 species of sponges, little over 400 species of mollusks and 350 species of 
marine crustaceans. There are also 7 species of dolphins, 9 species of whales, and 5 species of 
turtles, all of which endangered. The diversity of terrestrial ecosystems is limited by the small 
size of the land areas, shallow depth of the soil, and the relatively high soil salinity. In spite of 
this, more than 583 species of plants are found in the Maldives, of which 260 native species are 
recorded, and over 190 species of birds species are recorded, 9 of which are protected under 
the  Environmental  Law.  Between  1995  and  1999,  25  ‘Protected  Dive  Marine  Sites’  were 
delineated in the Maldives. 
   
  3.   Human and Economic Development 
 
5.   Tourism and fisheries are the cornerstones of the national economy. While fishing 
activity is well distributed nationally, about 75% of the tourist resorts lie within the Central 
Region, and within relatively easy reach of Malé Hulhulé International Airport. Malé is the 
transportation hub for all forms of transport. Tuna fisheries and the associated bait-fish fishing is 
a major industry in the Maldives accounting for a large but slowly declining proportion of the 
national economy. Agriculture including timber (mainly coconut), is of relatively minor economic 
importance and is also in slow decline. Apart from fisheries and tourism, there is little other 
industry except for ship building and ship maintenance in the atoll islands.  
 
6.   The national capital Malé (population 74,069 in 2000 Census) lies roughly at the mid 
point of the Central Regions and is the focus for virtually all of the industrial and commercial 
activity of the Maldives. The fact that 38% of the total population was enrolled at an educational 
institute in 2002, indicates the value placed on education. Focus Islands provide education up to 
secondary standard but for post-secondary education students have to go to Malé.
